title: 112_hr2328
content: The Act titled "End Excessive Oil Speculation Now Act of 2011" aims to eliminate excessive oil speculation. Congress finds that the national average retail price for a gallon of gasoline was $3.75 on June 8, 2011, causing economic pain to Americans. There is evidence that the spike in gasoline prices is due to Wall Street speculators, not supply and demand. Congress aims to bring relief to consumers and businesses at the gas pump. On May 27, 2011, the supply of gasoline in the US was higher than 2 years ago, while the demand was lower. Exxon Mobil CEO stated oil should cost $60-$70 per barrel based on supply and demand. Goldman Sachs warned of speculators inflating oil prices by $27 a barrel on March 21, 2011. Delta Airlines mentioned the marginal cost of oil production on March 25, 2011. Hirst stated that the marginal cost of oil production is $60 to $70 a barrel. Saudi Arabian officials blamed speculators for a $40 increase in oil prices in 2008. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission aims to base oil and gasoline prices on supply and demand fundamentals, not speculation. Dodd-Frank Act requires the Commission to establish position limits to prevent excessive speculation in crude oil and gasoline trading. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has failed to impose position limits to prevent excessive speculation in crude oil and gasoline trading as required by the Dodd-Frank Act. The proposed position limits for derivatives are not set to go into effect until the first quarter of 2012, missing the statutory deadline and failing to address the issue of excessive speculation. The Dodd-Frank Act requires the elimination of excessive oil speculation through bona-fide hedge trading transactions that reduce risks for commercial enterprises. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates managing commercial enterprise risks by addressing potential changes in asset values, liabilities, and services to reduce risks associated with swap positions. The Dodd-Frank Act requires the Commission to establish speculative position limits within 14 days of enactment, related to swaps executed as bona-fide hedging transactions. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates the establishment of speculative position limits within 14 days of enactment for crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, or heating oil futures and swaps, in line with the New York Mercantile Exchange's position limits. The Dodd-Frank Act requires the establishment of speculative position limits for various contracts, including contracts listed by designated contract markets, contracts settled against prices of contracts listed on registered entities, and swap contracts that perform or affect trading. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates establishing speculative position limits for contracts, including those listed on designated markets and swap contracts that impact trading. Margin requirements of 12 percent are set for speculative trading in energy futures and swaps. Entities trading energy futures or swaps must register with the Commission as noncommercial participants. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates establishing speculative position limits for contracts, including those listed on designated markets and swap contracts that impact trading. Margin requirements of 12 percent are set for speculative trading in energy futures and swaps. Entities trading energy futures or swaps must register with the Commission as noncommercial participants and adhere to position limits and margin requirements to eliminate excessive speculation in the market. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates position limits and margin requirements for entities trading energy futures or swaps to prevent excessive speculation. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to adjust position limits as needed, with exemptions for bona-fide hedge trading. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates position limits and margin requirements for energy futures trading to prevent excessive speculation. The Commission can adjust position limits to ensure noncommercial participants or speculators do not exceed 35 percent of the total traders' positions in crude oil, gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, and heating oil markets. This Act will terminate when the Commission imposes position limits and increased margin requirements as required by the Dodd-Frank Act. The Dodd-Frank Act mandates position limits and margin requirements for energy futures trading to prevent excessive speculation. Congress believes that the proposed position limits for derivatives are insufficient to meet the Act's requirements.
